title: Ex-Factory Prices Inflation Drop
text:
27 August 2015 18:44 CET Ex-Factory Prices Inflation Drop By Daily Guide 
The year-on-year inflation in ex-factory prices of goods and services was 10.6 percent for July 2015 while the monthly change rate recorded 1.1 percent. 
This represented a 12.5 percentage point decrease relative to the rate recorded in June 2015 (23.1 percent). 
Dr Philomena Nyarko, Government Statistician, who disclosed this to the media in Accra yesterday, said while the manufacturing sub-sector recorded the highest year-on-year producer price inflation rate of 13.5 percent, the utilities sub-sector recorded 7.3 percent. 
The mining and quarrying sub-sector recorded the lowest year-on-year inflation rate of 1.5 percent. 
The manufacture of textiles recorded the highest inflation rate of 49.0 percent while the manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers recorded the lowest producer price inflation rate of -11.9 percent. 
The monthly changes in the producer price index indicated that manufacturing recorded the highest inflation rate of 3.1 percent, followed by the utilities sub-sector with 0.1 percent. 
Mining and quarrying sub-sector recorded the lowest producer inflation rate of -18.3 percent. 
The producer price inflation in the mining and quarrying sub-sector decreased by 28.5 percentage points over the June 2015 rate of 30.0 percent to record 1.5 percent in July 2015. 
The inflation rate in the petroleum sub-sector was 77.3 percent in July 2014, which later fluctuated until November, 2014 when it recorded a rate of 61.1 percent. 
Subsequently, the rate steadily declined to record -8.7 percent in March 2015 and -9.6 percent in May 2015 as a result of base drift effect and the decrease in ex-refinery prices of petroleum products. 
The rate, however, increased in June 2015 to record -0.01 percent as a result of the increase in petroleum prices but decreased to -6.4 percent in July 2015 due to base drift effect. 
By Samuel Boadi
